acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 3 from its 96h-LC50 = 11 mg/L for fish (Oryzias latipes) (Test for the Ecological Effect of Chemical Substances (Ministry of the Environment), 2008).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 500 mg/kg for guinea pigs (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Animal study data are not available. Although a fatal case resulting from an accident at a chemical plant has been reported (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), the assumable exposure routes includes inhalation of vapor and dermal absorption.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 200 mg/kg for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 3.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Harmful to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 3 since its acute toxicity is Category 3 and it is not rapidly degradable (BOD degradation rate: 0% (Biodegradation and Bioconcentration of Existing Chemical Substances under the Chemical Substances Control Law, 1981)).

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_solids.rationale: Classification is not possible since no data are available though the substance is classified into Division 6.1, PG II in UNRTDG (UN2671).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data from in vivo mutagenicity tests. From in vitro mutagenicity tests, there is a report of a negative Ames test (ACGIH (2001)).

hazardous_to_ozone.rationale: This substance is not listed in Annexes to the Montreal Protocol.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine in the molecule

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Auto-ignition point is >630 degC (GESTIS (2005)) exceeding 70 degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid (melting point <= 140 degC) substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on a result of "a slight, transient eye injury" following application to rabbit cornea (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 2B.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Although there is a report that "The substance is a strong base and would be expected to be mild-to-moderate dermal irritants" (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the classification is not possible from this information alone and classification was not possible due to lack of data.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: There is a case report of a chemical operator who spilled the substance during distillation in a chemical plant. The operator developed dizziness, headache, respiratory distress, and convulsions that progressed to death (ACGIH (2001)). In a second serious case, the exposed individual's symptoms included severe headaches and weakness followed by convulsions and a stuporous state that lasted several days (PATTY (4th, 1994)). In the clinical setting, 1 mg/kg administered IV in postoperative patients resulted in restlessness, confusion (seizures) and central nervous system excitation during the recovery period (HSDB (2009)). Based on the data, the substance was classified into Category 1 (central nervous system).
